models.title: Lotus Leaf Superhydrophobic Surface
models.environment: Semi-aquatic environment, muddy and dirty ponds
models.biome: Aquatic Freshwater Lentic (Lakes, Ponds, Rivers, Streams)
models.problem: Maintaining a clean surface in a dirty, semi-aquatic environment to ensure efficient photosynthesis and prevent pathogen growth.
models.solution: The lotus leaf employs a hierarchical surface structure combined with a low surface energy wax to achieve superhydrophobicity. This allows water to bead up and roll off the surface, collecting dirt and debris along the way, effectively self-cleaning the leaf.

functional_components.function: Creating microscale roughness on the leaf surface
functional_components.description: The lotus leaf surface is covered in papillae, which are protrusions ranging from 1 to 5 μm in height. These papillae create a microscale roughness that increases the surface area and reduces the contact area between the leaf and water droplets. This roughness is a key component of the superhydrophobic effect, as it promotes the formation of air pockets between the water droplet and the leaf surface.
categories: Structural: Form, Architecture, Scaffolding, Topology, Static Load Bearing

abstracted_design_principles.description: Creating a rough surface texture increases the surface area and reduces the contact area with external elements. This promotes the formation of gaps or pockets between the surface and contacting elements, influencing interaction and adhesion.
abstracted_design_principles.low_abstraction: Minimize surface contact by introducing microscale protrusions.
abstracted_design_principles.high_abstraction: Control interfacial interactions using surface irregularities.

functional_components.function: Creating nanoscale roughness on the microscale papillae
functional_components.description: Each papilla is covered with nanoscale, hair-like structures. These nanostructures further increase the surface roughness and reduce the contact area between the leaf and water droplets. The combination of micro- and nanoscale roughness creates a hierarchical structure that is highly effective at repelling water.
categories: Structural: Form, Architecture, Scaffolding, Topology, Static Load Bearing

abstracted_design_principles.description: Creating a hierarchical structure with roughness at multiple scales enhances a surface's ability to repel liquids by minimizing the contact area between the surface and the liquid.
abstracted_design_principles.low_abstraction: Reduce surface adhesion by creating multi-scale textures
abstracted_design_principles.high_abstraction: Minimize surface interactions using hierarchical structuring

functional_components.description: The lotus leaf surface is coated with a layer of epicuticular wax crystalloids. This wax has a low surface energy, which means that it does not attract water molecules. The combination of low surface energy and hierarchical roughness creates a surface that is highly repellent to water.
categories: Chemical: Reactions, Catalysis, Sensing (Chemoreception), Signaling, Synthesis, Material Composition

abstracted_design_principles.description: Surface energy reduction minimizes attraction to external substances, promoting repellency. This is achieved by employing materials with inherently low surface energy characteristics.
abstracted_design_principles.low_abstraction: Minimize substance adhesion by employing low-energy materials.
abstracted_design_principles.high_abstraction: Reduce interaction by utilizing materials with tailored properties.

abstracted_design_principles.description: Hierarchical roughness, in combination with low surface energy, enhances repellency by minimizing the contact area between the surface and external substances.
abstracted_design_principles.low_abstraction: Enhance surface repellency by combining low-energy materials with hierarchical textures.
abstracted_design_principles.high_abstraction: Control surface interaction by integrating material properties with structural features.

functional_components.function: Trapping air between the water droplet and the leaf surface
functional_components.description: The hierarchical micro/nanostructure and low surface energy wax allow air to be trapped under the floating water drops. This trapped air further reduces the contact area between the water droplet and the leaf surface, contributing to the superhydrophobic and self-cleaning behavior of the lotus leaf. The air pocket minimizes adhesion between the water and the solid surface.
categories: Fluidic: Fluid Dynamics (Air/Water), Flow Control, Drag Reduction, Lift, Transport

abstracted_design_principles.description: Air is trapped between a liquid and a surface due to a combination of surface texture and low surface energy material properties. This trapped air reduces the contact area between the liquid and the surface, minimizing adhesion.
abstracted_design_principles.low_abstraction: Minimize surface adhesion by trapping gas between interfaces.
abstracted_design_principles.high_abstraction: Reduce interfacial contact using an intermediate layer.
